title: January 6 United States Capitol attack
added: In the days following the riots, multiple social media companies and tech giants began suspending or permanently banning several accounts and users that spread or aided the conspiracy theories that led the storming of the capitol. [[Facebook]], along with [[Twitter]], [[Instagram]], and [[Snapchat]], permanently suspended President Trump's account's on their platforms. Twitter also suspended Trump allies [[Michael Flynn]], his former national security advisor, along with [[Sidney Powell]] and [[L. Lin Wood|Lin Wood]], two attornies who represented Trump in his [[2020 United States presidential election|efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election]]. [[Steve Bannon]], a political strategist who was a trump adviser during the early days of the trump administration, was banned from twitter when he tweeted that he wanted top infectious disease expert [[Anthony Fauci]] and FBI director [[Christopher A. Wray]] to be beheaded.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Dzhanova|first=Yelena|title=Here are the most prominent people who got banned from social media platforms after the Capitol riots|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/people-banned-social-media-platforms-after-capitol-riots-2021-1|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Business Insider}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-08|title=Twitter bans Trump allies Michael Flynn and Sidney Powell in QAnon purge|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/twitter-flynn-powell-qanon-purge-b1784718.html|access-date=2021-02-11|website=The Independent|language=en}}</ref> Rep. [[Marjorie Taylor Greene|Marjorie Taylor Greene's]] twitter account was suspended for a month following reports of her calling for the execution of prominent democratic leaders.<ref>{{Cite web|last=EST|first=Jason Murdock On 1/15/21 at 6:11 AM|date=2021-01-15|title=Twitter blocks leave Donald Trump, Lin Wood, others silent during Joe Biden inauguration|url=https://www.newsweek.com/twitter-blocks-donald-trump-lin-wood-silent-joe-biden-inauguration-1561851|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Newsweek|language=en}}</ref> [[Mike Lindell]], an american inventor and owner of [[My Pillow]], was banned from twitter after spreading multiple conspiracy theories about the 2020 election.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Business|first=Donie O'Sullivan, CNN|title=MyPillow CEO Mike Lindell has been banned from Twitter|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/business/mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-intl-hnk/index.html|access-date=2021-02-11|website=CNN}}</ref> Others include conservative protest strategist [[Ali Alexander]],<ref>{{Cite news|last=Sommer|first=Will|date=2021-01-11|title=‘Stop the Steal’ Organizer in Hiding After Denying Blame for Riot|language=en|work=The Daily Beast|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/stop-the-steal-organizer-in-hiding-after-denying-blame-for-riot|access-date=2021-02-11}}</ref> along with [[Jim Watkins (businessman)|Jim Watkins]] and [[Ron Watkins]], the operators of 8kun (formally known as 8chan). In total twitter banned over 70,000 accounts on the basis of spreading misimformation, such as [[QAnon]] and other far-right conspiracy theories.<ref>{{Cite news|date=2021-01-12|title=Twitter Bans Over 70,000 QAnon Accounts in Conspiracy Crackdown|language=en|work=Bloomberg.com|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-12/twitter-bans-over-70-000-qanon-accounts-in-conspiracy-crackdown|access-date=2021-02-11}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|last=Conger|first=Kate|date=2021-01-12|title=Twitter, in Widening Crackdown, Removes Over 70,000 QAnon Accounts|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/11/technology/twitter-removes-70000-qanon-accounts.html|access-date=2021-02-11|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Other social media companies, such as [[Twitch (service)|Twitch]] and [[YouTube]], deleted accounts of President Trump and his allies, with Twitch banning their "PogChamp" emote because the subject of the emote spread anti-vax conspiracy theories. Their parent companies [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] and [[Google]], along with [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], took the social media app [[Parler]] of their respective app stores. On the basis that Parler didn't try to fight misimformation on their platform.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Business|first=Shannon Liao, CNN|title=PogChamp emote deleted for ties to Capitol violence|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/07/tech/pogchamp-emote-banned-capitol-hill-trnd/index.html|access-date=2021-02-11|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Nicas|first=Jack|last2=Alba|first2=Davey|date=2021-01-10|title=Amazon, Apple and Google Cut Off Parler, an App That Drew Trump Supporters|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/09/technology/apple-google-parler.html|access-date=2021-02-11|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: January 6 United States Capitol attack
deleted: In the days following the riots, multiple social media companies and tech giants began suspending or permanently banning several accounts and users that spread or aided the conspiracy theories that led the storming of the Capitol. [[Facebook]], along with [[Twitter]], [[Instagram]], and [[Snapchat]], permanently suspended President Trump's account's on their platforms. Twitter also suspended Trump allies [[Michael Flynn]], his former national security advisor, along with [[Sidney Powell]] and [[L. Lin Wood|Lin Wood]], two attornies who represented Trump in his [[2020 United States presidential election|efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election]]. [[Steve Bannon]], a political strategist who was a Trump adviser during the early days of the Trump administration, was banned from Twitter when he tweeted that he wanted top infectious disease expert [[Anthony Fauci]] and FBI director [[Christopher A. Wray]] to be beheaded.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Dzhanova|first=Yelena|title=Here are the most prominent people who got banned from social media platforms after the Capitol riots|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/people-banned-social-media-platforms-after-capitol-riots-2021-1|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Business Insider}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-08|title=Twitter bans Trump allies Michael Flynn and Sidney Powell in QAnon purge|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/twitter-flynn-powell-qanon-purge-b1784718.html|access-date=2021-02-11|website=The Independent|language=en}}</ref> Rep. [[Marjorie Taylor Greene|Marjorie Taylor Greene's]] Twitter account was suspended for a month following reports of her calling for the execution of prominent democratic leaders.<ref>{{Cite web|last=EST|first=Jason Murdock On 1/15/21 at 6:11 AM|date=2021-01-15|title=Twitter blocks leave Donald Trump, Lin Wood, others silent during Joe Biden inauguration|url=https://www.newsweek.com/twitter-blocks-donald-trump-lin-wood-silent-joe-biden-inauguration-1561851|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Newsweek|language=en}}</ref> [[Mike Lindell]], an American inventor and owner of [[My Pillow]], was banned from Twitter after spreading multiple conspiracy theories about the 2020 election.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Business|first=Donie O'Sullivan, CNN|title=MyPillow CEO Mike Lindell has been banned from Twitter|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/business/mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-intl-hnk/index.html|access-date=2021-02-11|website=CNN}}</ref> Others include conservative protest strategist [[Ali Alexander]],<ref>{{Cite news|last=Sommer|first=Will|date=2021-01-11|title=‘Stop the Steal’ Organizer in Hiding After Denying Blame for Riot|language=en|work=The Daily Beast|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/stop-the-steal-organizer-in-hiding-after-denying-blame-for-riot|access-date=2021-02-11}}</ref> along with [[Jim Watkins (businessman)|Jim Watkins]] and [[Ron Watkins]], the operators of [[8kun]] (formerly known as 8chan). In total Twitter banned over 70,000 accounts on the basis of spreading misinformation, such as [[QAnon]] and other far-right conspiracy theories.<ref>{{Cite news|date=2021-01-12|title=Twitter Bans Over 70,000 QAnon Accounts in Conspiracy Crackdown|language=en|work=Bloomberg.com|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-12/twitter-bans-over-70-000-qanon-accounts-in-conspiracy-crackdown|access-date=2021-02-11}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|last=Conger|first=Kate|date=2021-01-12|title=Twitter, in Widening Crackdown, Removes Over 70,000 QAnon Accounts|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/11/technology/twitter-removes-70000-qanon-accounts.html|access-date=2021-02-11|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Other social media companies, such as [[Twitch (service)|Twitch]] and [[YouTube]], deleted accounts of Trump and his allies, with Twitch banning the [[PogChamp]] [[emote]] because the subject of the emote spread [[anti-vaccination]] conspiracy theories. [[Google]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] and [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] took the social media app [[Parler]] off their respective app stores and servers, on the basis that Parler didn't try to fight misinformation on their platform.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Business|first=Shannon Liao, CNN|title=PogChamp emote deleted for ties to Capitol violence|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/07/tech/pogchamp-emote-banned-capitol-hill-trnd/index.html|access-date=2021-02-11|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Nicas|first=Jack|last2=Alba|first2=Davey|date=2021-01-10|title=Amazon, Apple and Google Cut Off Parler, an App That Drew Trump Supporters|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/09/technology/apple-google-parler.html|access-date=2021-02-11|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: January 6 United States Capitol attack
added: ===Federal Lawsuit Accusing Trump and Giuliani of Inciting Capitol Riot===

On 16 February 2021, Trump was sued by the nation's oldest civil rights organization, the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]] on behalf of the House Homeland Security chairman Bennie Thompson of Mississippi for conspiring to incite the violent assault at the Capitol.<ref>[https://naacp.org/latest/naacp-files-federal-lawsuit-accusing-trump-and-giuliani-of-inciting-u-s-capitol-riot NAACP Files Federal Lawsuit Accusing Trump and Giuliani of Inciting U.S. Capitol Riot]</ref> Included in the federal lawsuit as defendants are Trump's former personal lawyer Giuliani, and the two [[neo-fascist]], [[far-right]] organizations [[Proud Boys]] and [[Oath Keepers]]. The lawsuit alleges that, by preventing - "by the use of force, intimidation, and threat" - the Congress from carrying out its constitutional duties, Trump, Giuliani and the [[hate group]]s directly violated the 1871 [[Ku Klux Klan Act]]. The law was first passed following the Civil War to combat the [[Ku Klux Klan]] violence and allow African Americans to take action against hate groups who use “force, intimidation, or threat” to prevent leaders from doing the duties of their office.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/16/us/politics/naacp-sues-trump-giuliani-proud-boys-capitol.html N.A.A.C.P. Sues Trump and Giuliani Over Election Fight and Jan. 6 Riot]</ref><ref>[https://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/how-1871-ku-klux-klan-act-being-used-latest-trump-n1258132 How the 1871 Ku Klux Klan Act is being used in this latest Trump lawsuit]</ref><ref>[https://www.npr.org/2021/02/16/968374210/house-democrat-sues-trump-giuliani-and-2-far-right-groups-over-capitol-riot House Democrat Sues Trump, Giuliani And 2 Far-Right Groups Over Capitol Riot]</ref>

The lawsuit alleges that by preventingCongress from carrying out its constitutional duties"by the use of force, intimidation, and threat", Trump, Giuliani and the [[hate group]]s directly violated the 1871 [[Ku Klux Klan Act]]. The law was first passed following the Civil War to combat the [[Ku Klux Klan]] violence and allow African Americans to take action against hate groups who use"force, intimidation, orthreat"to prevent leaders from doing the duties of their office.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/16/us/politics/naacp-sues-trump-giuliani-proud-boys-capitol.html N.A.A.C.P. Sues Trump and Giuliani Over Election Fight and Jan. 6 Riot]</ref><ref>[https://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/how-1871-ku-klux-klan-act-being-used-latest-trump-n1258132 How the 1871 Ku Klux Klan Act is being used in this latest Trump lawsuit]</ref><ref>[https://www.npr.org/2021/02/16/968374210/house-democrat-sues-trump-giuliani-and-2-far-right-groups-over-capitol-riot House Democrat Sues Trump, Giuliani And 2 Far-Right Groups Over Capitol Riot]</ref>
